body: It would be helpful if you can either get a small project that demonstrates the failure or point me to an open source project that has the behavior.
I would have to create an example to reproduce as the real project is propietary and I can't share. Let me try to create small example tomorrow to reproduce.

The reproducable example can be found here....

https://github.com/marcofranssen/go-swagger-issue

```bash
marco@DESKTOP-B249DU4 MINGW64 /c/code/go-swagger-issue (master)
$ make
Generate code

marco@DESKTOP-B249DU4 MINGW64 /c/code/go-swagger-issue (master)
$ make
Generate code

marco@DESKTOP-B249DU4 MINGW64 /c/code/go-swagger-issue (master)
$ make
Generate code
diff --git a/docs/swagger.json b/docs/swagger.json
index 42ce3b3..991b945 100644
--- a/docs/swagger.json
+++ b/docs/swagger.json
@@ -47,6 +47,26 @@
     }
   },
   "definitions": {
+    "Example": {
+      "description": "Example the response of an example resource",
+      "type": "object",
+      "properties": {
+        "description": {
+          "type": "string",
+          "x-go-name": "Description"
+        },
+        "priority": {
+          "type": "integer",
+          "format": "int64",
+          "x-go-name": "Priority"
+        },
+        "title": {
+          "type": "string",
+          "x-go-name": "Title"
+        }
+      },
+      "x-go-package": "github.com/marcofranssen/go-swagger-issue/domain"
+    },
     "ExampleListResponse": {
       "description": "ExampleListResponse the response of a list of example resources",
       "type": "object",

marco@DESKTOP-B249DU4 MINGW64 /c/code/go-swagger-issue (master)
$ make
Generate code

marco@DESKTOP-B249DU4 MINGW64 /c/code/go-swagger-issue (master)
$ make
Generate code

marco@DESKTOP-B249DU4 MINGW64 /c/code/go-swagger-issue (master)
$ make
Generate code
diff --git a/docs/swagger.json b/docs/swagger.json
index 42ce3b3..991b945 100644
--- a/docs/swagger.json
+++ b/docs/swagger.json
@@ -47,6 +47,26 @@
     }
   },
   "definitions": {
+    "Example": {
+      "description": "Example the response of an example resource",
+      "type": "object",
+      "properties": {
+        "description": {
+          "type": "string",
+          "x-go-name": "Description"
+        },
+        "priority": {
+          "type": "integer",
+          "format": "int64",
+          "x-go-name": "Priority"
+        },
+        "title": {
+          "type": "string",
+          "x-go-name": "Title"
+        }
+      },
+      "x-go-package": "github.com/marcofranssen/go-swagger-issue/domain"
+    },
     "ExampleListResponse": {
       "description": "ExampleListResponse the response of a list of example resources",
       "type": "object",
```

I can reproduce this.  I'll need to continue looking for why this occurs. The output changes because go maps randomize order. And it looks like when `ExampleResponse` gets processed first things work out fine, but when the `ExampleListResponse` gets processed first it doesn't add the base type as discovered model

The relevant debug output is:

Adds elements:
```
2019/10/05 15:22:18 got the named type object: github.com/marcofranssen/go-swagger-issue/api.ExampleResponse | isAlias: false | exported: true

```

```
2019/10/05 15:22:39 skipping field "Title" for allOf scan because not anonymous

2019/10/05 15:22:39 field Title: string(*types.Basic) ["json:\"title\""] ==>

```
@casualjim @fredbi - Can we expect solution for this issue in any time sooner.?

> And it looks like when ExampleResponse gets processed first things work out fine, but when the ExampleListResponse gets processed first it doesn't add the base type as discovered model

@casualjim I think it's not about which model is processed first. I found out that the `Models` map while iterating over is being updated with new embedded models (btw. should that happen?). Sometimes loop will not read new entries from the map that's why we have inconsistent results.

That's the place where it happens:
https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/blob/3552147e71fdc4346fa205161a7ff8801c2af430/codescan/spec.go#L196 

I solved that by copying the `s.ctx.app.Models` map to new one before processing. What do you think @casualjim @fredbi? If the solution is ok with you then I can create a PR.

issue.title: Fix patch requests send from go-kubermatic client

labels.name: size/XXL
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 1000+ lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: lgtm
labels.description: Indicates that a PR is ready to be merged.

labels.name: approved
labels.description: Indicates a PR has been approved by an approver from all required OWNERS files.

labels.name: release-note-none
labels.description: Denotes a PR that doesn't merit a release note.

labels.name: dco-signoff: yes
labels.description: Denotes that all commits in the pull request have the valid DCO signoff message.

repository.name: kubermatic
repository.description: Kubermatic Kubernetes Platform - the Central Kubernetes Management Platform For Any Infrastructure

issue.body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
Currently, the generated go-kubermatic client is not able to send an appropriate PATCH request to the API server, it's because of the `Patch` field type which is `[]byte` ([example](https://github.com/kubermatic/kubermatic/pull/4917/files#diff-2ace21458585d6d9d5e1ce87136e0fdcL991)) instead it should be `json.RawMessage`. 

`[]byte` representation in JSON is base64 so the API server returns bad request code when receiving such a payload

Additionally, the go-swagger pkg must be upgraded to handle json.RawMessage type.

**Does this PR introduce a user-facing change?**:
<!--  Write your release note:
1. Enter your extended release note in the below block. If the PR requires additional action from users switching to the new release, include the string "action required".
2. If  no release note is required, just write "NONE".
-->
```release-note
NONE
```

issue.title: Different spec produced for same codebase

labels.name: generate spec
labels.description: Related to spec generation from code

issue.body:
## Problem statement

`go-swagger` generates different specs from the same codebase in repeated runs. The reason for this is a swagger annotated type embedding another one.

## Swagger specification

None.

## Steps to reproduce

Clone https://github.com/lukasmalkmus/swagger-issue
Follow the `README.md`

## Environment
swagger version: 0.21.0  
go version: 1.13.6  
OS:   macOS

I haven't had a deeper look yet. But the generator seems to act on one of the two types in question randomly. Since I usually trust the stdlib when it comes to loading the code packages, I suspect the bug in question could be caused by getting data from a map (since maps are randomly orderer, we get different types on different runs).

body: I created a fix for that https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/pull/2209
